If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will always abide in a wonderful, concentrated mind.
What are the ten?
First, skillfully practicing mindfulness of the body;
second, skillfully practicing mindfulness of feelings;
third, skillfully practicing mindfulness of mind;
fourth, skillfully practicing mindfulness of dharmas;
fifth, skillfully practicing mindfulness of objects;
sixth, skillfully practicing mindfulness of the araá¹‡ya;
seventh, skillfully practicing mindfulness of royal capitals, countries, cities, and villages;
eighth, skillfully practicing mindfulness of fame, profit, offerings, and so forth;
ninth, skillfully practicing mindfulness of the training methods established by the TathÄgata;
Tenth, the mindfulness of skillfully severing afflictions and secondary afflictions and the defilements.
Good sons!
What is the bodhisattva's skillful practice of mindfulness of the body?
It means that all the sinful and unwholesome dharmas that arise from the self in the bodhisattva's body are carefully discerned with superior wisdom and completely abandoned.

Moreover, observing the faults of the body, from the soles of the feet up to the crown of the head, bound by sinews and vessels, thoroughly observing the body, completely devoid of self, unable to remain for a moment, subject to decay, this body is impure, foul-smelling, disgusting, and composed of various unpleasant appearances.
When the bodhisattva contemplates in this way, if there is any craving and desire in the body, the notion of self in the body, or attachment to the body, none of these dharmas can be obtained.
For this reason, all unwholesome dharmas that accompany the body cannot be mastered, while all wholesome dharmas that accompany the body can be mastered.
This is called skillfully practicing mindfulness of the body.
What is meant by 'skillfully practicing mindfulness of feelings'?
It means that a bodhisattva thinks like this:
'All feelings are suffering.
How can foolish people mistakenly take them to be happiness?

Foolish people do not recognize suffering and happiness. Only the sages fully know them to be suffering. After the bodhisattva himself diligently practices to end suffering, he also teaches others to do the same.'

When the bodhisattva contemplates in this way, he does not give rise to attachment or anger towards those feelings. After practicing diligently himself, he also causes others to study in the same way. This is called skillfully practicing mindfulness of feelings.
What is meant by 'skillfully practicing mindfulness of mind'?
It means that a bodhisattva thinks like this:

'The mind is actually impermanent but grasps at it as permanent, takes suffering as happiness, the non-self as self, and the impure as pure. It is agitated and cannot remain still for a moment, like a light and fickle wind. It is the original root of afflictions and also the condition for the secondary afflictions, opening the door to evil destinies and destroying good destinies.

Moreover, it is the condition for the arising of greed, anger, and delusion. It is the supreme ruler of all dharmas. The mind is the forerunner of all dharmas. If the mind has knowledge, then all dharmas also have something to be known.

The mind is like a painter painting various images. The mind does not see the mind. The mind can accumulate good and bad karma. This mind cycles like a whirling fire wheel. This mind spins rapidly like a galloping horse. The mind is like a wild fire blazing and burning. The mind is like great water nourishing various things.

When the bodhisattva contemplates in this way, the mind is actually not free. The bodhisattvas themselves can subdue the mind. If the mind is subdued, then all dharmas are subdued. This is called skillfully practicing the mindfulness of mind.
What is the bodhisattvas' skillful practice of the mindfulness of dharmas?

It is said that the bodhisattvas truly understand unwholesome dharmas, namely greed, anger, delusion, and so forth, and their bases. The antidotes to greed are the remaining unwholesome dharmas, and the antidotes to anger and delusion are the unwholesome dharmas.
The bodhisattvas diligently eliminate these unwholesome dharmas and then are able to understand all wholesome dharmas.

Within wholesome dharmas, they give rise to a mind of delight and abide in right mindfulness. They seek to accomplish those dharmas, practice them themselves, and also teach others to cultivate and study in this way. This is called skillfully practicing the mindfulness of dharmas.
What is the bodhisattvas' skillful practice of the mindfulness of objects?
It means that if a bodhisattva, regarding all agreeable and disagreeable forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, does not give rise to craving or anger,
the bodhisattva thinks like this:

I should not now give rise to craving for this dharma which is devoid of essence. If one gives rise to craving, then one is a foolish person, possessing the nature of foolishness, the nature of lack of clarity, the nature of unwholesomeness.

As the Buddha has said, if one gives rise to craving, then one gives rise to attachment, foolishness, and grasping, and is unable to discriminate wholesome and unwholesome dharmas. For this reason, one falls into evil destinies.
The bodhisattva further thinks like this:

I should not now give rise to anger towards this empty dharma. Giving rise to anger means being unable to endure and giving rise to anger, being criticized by the sages, and being abandoned by fellow practitioners of pure conduct.

When the bodhisattva contemplates in this way, he is not destroyed by objects and does not become attached to what he has attained. The bodhisattva himself practices in this way and also teaches others to study in the same way. This is called the mindfulness of skillfully practicing the realm.
What is the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of skillfully practicing the solitary place?
It is said that the bodhisattva thinks like this:
Cultivating the practice of non-disputation and the practice of tranquility is called dwelling in a solitary place.
There are devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas and others with the supernormal knowledge of others' minds who can know my mind and mental factors.

Therefore, I should now stay far away from improper attention and different thoughts, and always stay away from improper attention in all places. I should give rise to mental delight and extensively cultivate and practice in the proper Dharma.
This is called the mindfulness of skillfully practicing the solitary place.
What is the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of skillfully practicing the royal capital, country, city, and village?

It means that when a bodhisattva enters a royal capital, a country, or a village, he should give rise to the practices of a bodhisattva, and completely abandon all improper places, and also completely abandon places that are not suitable for one who has left the household life.
What are the places that are not suitable for one who has left the household life?

Namely, the residences of kings and officials, gambling dens, wine shops and banquets, places where singing, dancing, and entertainment are performed, and all other places that are not suitable for one who has left the household life - he should stay far away from them and not go to any of them.
This is called the mindfulness of skillfully practicing in the royal capital, country, and village.
What is the bodhisattva's mindfulness of skillfully practicing fame, profit, and offerings, etc.?
It means that when a bodhisattva encounters fame, profit, offerings, etc., he only accepts them in accordance with the arising of the mind of the donor in order to make him a field of merit.

However, in receiving them, they do not give rise to craving or attachment, nor do they grasp at them, thinking of them as their own, or give rise to the notion of possession. They share whatever they obtain with all sentient beings, providing sustenance for those who are suffering and distressed.
For this reason, they do not become arrogant or conceited about matters such as fame, gain, and support, nor do they indulge in arrogance and self-indulgence.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:

'All matters such as fame, gain, and support, whether one's own or others', arise temporarily and do not last long. Because they arise temporarily, at all times and in all places, nothing can be obtained.
What wise person would give rise to a mind of attachment and arrogance towards these impermanent, short-lived, insubstantial, and unstable phenomena?'
This is called the mindfulness of skillfully practicing matters such as fame, gain, and support.

It is said that the bodhisattva thinks like this:

All tathÄgatas of the past have studied in this way, and by studying in this way, they have already attained perfect enlightenment and entered great nirvÄá¹‡a;ğŸ”½All tathÄgatas of the future will study in this way, and by studying in this way, they will attain perfect enlightenment and enter great nirvÄá¹‡a;
And all tathÄgatas of the present are also studying in this way, and by studying in this way, they are presently attaining perfect enlightenment and entering great nirvÄá¹‡a.
For this reason, they give rise to a pure mind towards this gate of study, and with respect and diligence, they cultivate and practice it.
This is called the good practice of the mindfulness gate established by the TathÄgata.
What is the bodhisattvas' mindfulness of skillfully severing afflictions and secondary afflictions?
It means that because the bodhisattva is well-versed in mindfulness, he is able to thoroughly understand all afflictions, secondary afflictions, and defiled dharmas.
What causes do they arise from? What conditions do they originate from?

The bodhisattva fully understands such causes and such conditions, and thus completely abandons them. This is called the mindfulness of skillfully severing afflictions, secondary afflictions, and defilements.
Good man!
If the bodhisattva cultivates these ten kinds of dharmas, he will always abide in a marvelous, concentrated mind.
Moreover, good man!
If the bodhisattva cultivates ten kinds of dharmas, he will always wear cast-off rags.
What are the ten?
First, firm vows;
Second, humility;
Third, no weariness;
Fourth, free from all attachments;
Fifth, not seeing faults;
Sixth, only seeing merits;
Seventh, not praising oneself;
Eighth, not slandering others;
Ninth, fully endowed with precepts;
Tenth, being close to sages and worthies.
Good sons!
What is meant by bodhisattvas' vows being firm, and being close to sages and worthies?

It means that if a bodhisattva himself has pure faith and a complete will, and is trusted by the TathÄgatas, even if he encounters circumstances that would endanger his life, he will not violate the vows he has made, and will not change his vows.
Because he is able to make his vows firm, he is able to humble his mind and not give rise to arrogance.
Because his mind is humble, he is able to take all the despised and discarded things of people.
Having taken them, he washes, dyes, sews, and mends them, without giving rise to disgust or weariness.
Because of being tireless, following what is done, free from all attachments, up to the completion of the cultivation of superior karma, one is able to not see faults in this rag robe.
Although it is said that this robe is tattered, old, and has many lice and fleas, if it is worn on the body and gives rise to defilement, the bodhisattva will never see its faults.
Why is it that this robe only sees merits?

That is to say, this rag robe is worn by sages, and the noble ones who are free from desires all follow it. Because it accords with the noble lineage, it is praised by the Buddha as auspicious and praised by the Buddha.
For this reason, one does not praise oneself or slander others. Because of being free from praising oneself and slandering others, one is able to be fully endowed with precepts.

Because of being fully endowed with pure precepts, he is close to all sages and worthies, praised by the buddhas, and guarded by the bodhisattvas. Humans, non-humans, and others all come to assist him. Brahmins, ká¹£atriyas, and all the people come to pay homage and respect him. Fellow practitioners of the same precepts all praise him.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will always wear rag robes.

If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will only accept the three robes.
What are the ten?
First, contentment;
Second, few desires;
Third, being far removed from seeking;
Fourth, being free from hoarding;
Fifth, being free from hoarding, therefore nothing is lost;
Sixth, being without loss, therefore free from all suffering and distress;
Seventh, being free from displeasure;
Eighth, being far removed from sorrow and lamentation;
Ninth, having nothing to receive;
Tenth, diligently practicing, therefore attaining the destruction of defilements.
Good man!
What is meant by bodhisattvas being content, up to diligently practicing, therefore attaining the destruction of defilements?

It means that if bodhisattvas are content with whatever robes they obtain, because of contentment they are able to have few desires. Because of few desires, they do not seek anything and are free from hoarding. Because of not hoarding, nothing is lost;
Because of not losing, they are free from the suffering and distress that arises from loss;
Because they are free from suffering and distress, there is nothing unpleasant; because they are free from unpleasantness, there is no sorrow or lamentation;

because there is no sorrow or lamentation, there is nothing to be received; because there is nothing to be received, they diligently practice and cultivate, and thus attain the exhaustion of defilements.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will only accept the three robes.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they do not follow the practices of others.
What are the ten?
First, they do not follow the practice of greed;
second, they do not follow the practice of anger;
third, they do not follow the practice of delusion;
fourth, they do not follow the practice of hatred and harm;
fifth, they do not follow the practice of stinginess and jealousy;
sixth, they do not follow the practice of self-conceit;
seventh, they do not follow the practice of seeking fame and reputation from others;
eighth, they do not follow the practice of seeking after offerings;
ninth, they do not follow the practice of paying homage to celestial demons;
tenth, not following high-mindedness, attachment, and love in one's conduct.
These are called not following others in one's conduct.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will not follow others in their conduct.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will always go on alms rounds.
What are the ten?
First, practicing going on alms rounds in order to accept and embrace sentient beings;
second, practicing going on alms rounds in sequence;
third, practicing going on alms rounds without giving rise to fatigue;
fourth, practicing going on alms rounds with contentment;
fifth, practicing going on alms rounds in order to distribute [the alms];
sixth, practicing going on alms rounds without being attached;
seventh, practicing going on alms rounds with a good understanding of moderation;ğŸ”½eighth, practicing going on alms rounds in order to make wholesome qualities manifest;
ninth, practicing going on alms rounds in order to perfect all wholesome roots;
Tenth, in order to eliminate the notion of body, one practices begging for food.
Good sons!
What is meant by bodhisattvas accepting sentient beings, up to eliminating the notion of body and practicing begging for food?
It means that if bodhisattvas see sentient beings suffering with little wholesome roots, in order to accept and cause them to be replete with wholesome roots, they practice begging for food.

When bodhisattvas enter cities, towns, and villages to practice begging for food, they should abide in right mindfulness, be upright in body, dignified in movement and stillness, with proper deportment, their faculties tranquil, looking properly ahead, their thoughts focused on wholesome dharmas.

The food obtained by begging should be in accordance with the sequence, never abandoning poor houses to beg from the wealthy. That is to say, in the houses of brahmins, ká¹£atriyas, elders, householders, and great clans, going from one to the next, begging in sequence, obtaining food and drink, knowing the proper amount and being content, only excluding special cases, not going everywhere.

As for 'different places,' it means the homes of vicious dogs and livestock, and the houses of those who have newly given birth to calves. One who destroys pure precepts and falls into the animal realm, who is able to cause disturbance, whether male or female, boy or girl, is despised by all. One should stay far away from such places.
Because of sequentially begging for food, one does not become tired or reviled. One does not give rise to attachment or anger towards those beings, nor does one despise them.

The food one obtains, one should accept as appropriate and be content. Having accepted it, one returns to the monastery, puts away one's robes and alms bowl, washes one's hands and feet, makes offerings with respect and reverence in front of an image of the TathÄgata or a stÅ«pa of the TathÄgata, and then enters one's own quarters to divide the alms food into four parts:

One part is given to fellow practitioners of the precepts, one part is given to poor and suffering beings, one part is given to those who have fallen into the evil destinies, and one part is eaten by oneself.

Although the bodhisattva accepts their food, he does not give rise to defiled attachment, does not become arrogant or self-indulgent, and does not grasp at it. He accepts the food only to sustain his body, neither making it extremely emaciated nor extremely heavy.
Why is this?
If it is extremely emaciated, it interferes with cultivating wholesome dharmas. If it is extremely heavy, it increases sleepiness.

In order to make wholesome practices manifest, the bodhisattva, after accepting food, gives rise to diligence and abandons laziness. Gradually he should cultivate and progress in the factors of enlightenment, causing them to be perfected. Because he cultivates and perfects the factors of enlightenment, he does not give rise to the grasping of self, and because he does not grasp at self, he is able to give his body and flesh to sentient beings.
Good man!
If the bodhisattva cultivates these ten kinds of dharmas, he will always go on alms rounds.
